lines.text: Maybe it'll stop you trying to be so desperate about making more money than you can ever use? You can't take it with you, Mr. Kirby. So what good is it? As near as I can see, the only thing you can take with you is the love of your friends.
[last lines]

[offering grace]
Quiet, please, quiet! Well, sir, here we are again. We've had quite a time of it lately, but it seems that the worst of it is over. Course, the fireworks all blew up, but we can't very well blame that on you. Anyway, everything's turned out fine, as it usually does. Alice is going to marry Tony; Mr. Kirby, who's turned out to be a very good egg, sold us back our house - he'll probably forget all about big deals for a while. Nobody on our block has to move; and, with the right handling, I think we can even thaw out Mrs. Kirby here. We've all got our health; as far as anything else is concerned, we still leave that up to you. Thank you. Bring it on, Reba!
Lincoln said, "With malice toward none, with charity to all." Nowadays they say, "Think the way I do or I'll bomb the daylights outta you."
Penny, why don't you write a play about Ism-Mania?
Ism-Mania?
Yeah, sure, you know, Communism, Faschism, Voodoo-ism, everybody's got an -ism these days.
Oh
[laughs]
I thought it was some kind of itch or something.
Well, it's just as catching. When things go a little bad nowadays, you go out, get yourself an -ism and you're in business.

[offering grace]
Well, Sir, here we are again. We've been getting along pretty good for quite a while now - we're certainly much obliged. Remember all we ask is just to go along the way we are, keep our health; as far as anything else is concerned, we leave that up to you. Thank you.
I ain't done nothing but I sure is tired.
Yeah you always tired, for once you was born tired. Go set the table.
I don't see why I gots to do your work just because we's engaged.
You're an idiot, Mr. Kirby.
What?
A stupid idiot.
You can't talk to me like that.

Oh, yes I can. Scum, are we? What makes you think you're such a superior human being? Your money? If you do, you're a dull-witted fool, Mr. Kirby. And a poor one at that. You're poorer than any of these people you call scum, because I'll guarantee at least they've got some friends. While you with your jungle and your long claws, as you call 'em, you'll wind up your miserable existence without anything you can call friend. You may be a high mogul to yourself, Mr. Kirby, but to me you're a failure - failure as a man, failure as a human being, even a failure as a father. When your time comes, I doubt if a single tear will be shed over you. The world will probably cry, "Good riddance." That's a nice prospect, Mr. Kirby. I hope you'll enjoy it. I hope you'll get some comfort out of all this coin you've been sweating over then!
Sometimes you're so beautiful it just gags me.
How's Essie doing?
Confidentially, she stinks.
Oh well, as long as she's happy.
I resent what you said about your brain. I think it's beautiful.
You do, huh?
Mmmhm
I see. Yeah, that's probably the first thing you noticed about me that you liked - my colossal brain.
Well, no. No, it was the back of your head.
The back of my head? I've got a big bump back there. Well, what happened when I turned around?
Well, I figured I'd just have to get used to that.
Oh, you figured.
And, you know, it might not take very long, but I just figured I'd...
...you just figured you'd just... well, I'm glad you 'figured.'
Have you ever been in a monastery?
No, but I'm the fella who got caught in a cave once.
Were you? Whatever happened to you?
Well, the cave caved in and I haven't been heard from since.
It's for you.
Why bless my soul, a new harmonica.
I got it for you for your birthday.
How do you know when my birthday is? Even I don't know.
Anytime I get an impulse to get you something, that's your birthday.
...It takes courage. You know everybody's afraid to live.

You ought to hear Grandpa on that subject. You know he says most people nowadays are run by fear. Fear of what they eat, fear of what they drink, fear of their jobs, their future, fear of their health. They're scared to save money, and they're scared to spend it. You know what his pet aversion is? The people who commercialize on fear, you know they scare you to death so they can sell you something you don't need.
I can feel a scream coming on right now... it's up here, in my throat! It's fighting to get out!
No, please, don't scream!
[she screams]

[comes over]
What happened?
What happened? Well, there was a mouse!
A mouse in this place?
What do you mean, 'mouse'? It was a rat, *this* long, and it had hair on it! And there were six or seven of them!
What about you, Alice? Have you a family tree?
My dear sir, don't you know that a sycamore *is* a tree?
You know, every time I think about how lucky I am, I feel like screaming.
The die is cast. I'm a lily!
Have some popcorn.

[to Alice]
If you had any sense, young woman, you'd stay where you belong and stop being ambitious.
Shall I sock her, Alice?
How would you like to come over to our house and work on your gadgets?
Your house? Well I don't know, thank you.
Oh go on, you'll love it. Everybody at over at our place does just what he wants to do.
Really?
Mmm-hmmmm.
That must be wonderful. But how would I live?
The same way we do.
The same way? Well who takes care of you?
The same One that takes care of the lilies of the field, Mr. Poppins, except that we toil a little, spin a little, have a barrel of fun. If you want to, come on over and become a lily too.
If it's illegal to manufacture fireworks without a permit, then I guess we're guilty of that too, because we've been doing it a long time.
I don't feel guilty, do you, Essie?
No.

[phone rings. Tony won't let go of Alice's hands]
You know, it's a strange sensation - I seem to hear ringing in my ears.
Me, too. And I thought for a moment it was the telephone.
Yeah. I hear voices, too. Voices that say, if you don't kiss her soon, you're a chump.
You know, if I were really clever, I could answer the phone without the use of my hands.
Saw it done in a circus once.

[Alice picks up receiver with her teeth]
Hey, wonderful, you'd be a sensation on the trapeze!
What happened? You were allright last time I saw you.
One of my granddaughters dared me to slide down the banister.
Too bad, is it serious?
No, just a sprain or something. The thing I like most about it is the crutches, I've been wanting to walk on them ever since I was a kid. Haven't you?
Did you hear about it, Grandpa? We maybe all have to move.
Who said so?
Well everybody's talking about it, somebody's buying up everything.
I hear they're buying it up for a big factory or something.
My landlord told me he wouldn't have sold only they offered him so much money.
Nobody wants to move, Grandpa, you know that.
We just put up some shelves, cost $60.
I've been here for 20 years.
I think we should see somebody.
Now wait just a minute, don't get excited. We've all been neighbors for a long time, I know that. But if they're buying this property up for a factory, they'll need every foot of ground, won't they?
I guess so.
Well now suppose I won't sell them my place, what're they going to do?
That's right, you own your place.
Sure I do.
And they're going to need it too, won't they?
You bet they will, and it'll take more than money to make me sell my property. Now go on back to work, stop cluttering up the street, we'll all be arrested.
Why shouldn't Ed print up something about the fireworks and put them in the candy boxes? That would advertise the Revolution, wouldn't it?
Say..."Watch for the Revolution, it's coming soon!" How's that?
"Watch for the Revolution, it's coming soon"? Now I can use my big type.
We've got plenty of these red flags, you can write about that.
"The Red Flag will sweep the country, get your Red Flags from Sycamore!"
Do you have any Russian stamps for me?
No, nobody writes to me anymore. They are all dead.
Grandpa go to the graduation exercises today?
Guess so.
I wonder how many people Grandpa's going to bring home for dinner tonight.
I don't know, it all depends if he goes walking in a park.
Well let him bring them, I'll be ready for them.
What if all your deals fall through? Might be a good thing for you.
Man, you're crazy.

Well, maybe I am, but I used to be just like you once. Then one morning, when I was going up in the elevator... it struck me I wasn't having any fun. So I came right down and never went back. Yes, sir. That was 35 years ago.
You know, there never was anything in my life that I couldn't get if I didn't scream loud enough.
Really?
Yeah, and I've had plenty of practice with it since I was a baby. I'm pretty terrific at it now. Here, let me show you a little example.
[he screams, and the office boy opens the door]
[he screams again, and the office boy leaves]
[both laugh]
We're going to the Monte Carlo ballet!
...The Monte Carlo ballet? It stinks!

We can't just pop out of the building with no place to go. Very bad idea that, you know. I know two people that did that once - they went out of the building, they were uncertain, so they just walked and walked and walked and finally they just died... of hunger. Now you wouldn't want anything like that to happen... because if, if that happened... you're so beautiful.
There's only one thing worryin' me - has they got Relief up there?
Sure they is. They got Relief everywhere, now.
They do? Well, let's get on up there, then.
I feel so good, life is running around inside of me like a squirrel!
Donald, were you ever in a monastery?
No, I don't go no place much. I'm on relief.

[to the Kirby family]
The next time you want to go slumming, stay away from our neighbors!
Were you ever in a monestery, Mr. Poppins?
In a monastery?
What's the matter, Penny, stuck?
Yes, I've sort of got myself in the monastery and I can't get out.
It'll come to you, remember how you got out of that jail.

[to Martin]
Our records show you owe back income tax for 14 years.
Hey wait a minute, mister, that's too far back, that's outlawed ain't it?
What's your name?
What difference does that make?
You ever file a tax return?
No sir.
What was your income last year?
I don't know, about $50, wasn't it, Essie?
I don't know.
Why don't you go back to writing your war play, Mrs. Sycamore? I like that one best.
Really, Rheba? Well maybe I will.
Right up to the very last, she couldn't walk into a room without my heart going thump, thump, thump.
Mr. Vanderhoff, you once told me I was a failure as a father.
Oh, I didn't mean that.
I know, but I am.

[opening the car door for Kirby]
Good morning, Mr. Kirby.
Good morning.
